title: 108_hr5403
content: The Act titled "Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004" aims to improve the quality of long term care in skilled nursing facilities under Medicare. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 requires skilled nursing facilities to provide detailed reporting of nursing expenditures, including wages and benefits for different levels of nursing staff. Additionally, the Act mandates the development and reporting of new quality measures by the Secretary. The Secretary is required to develop quality measures for use in a payment system, in consultation with experts and stakeholders. These measures may include process, structural, and outcome measures that are valid, reliable, and structured for data collection. The Secretary is mandated to develop quality measures for the Medicare program, including risk-adjusted outcome measures, valid and reliable measures, and measures that address nursing home staffing levels. Special provisions are to be made for small skilled nursing facilities. The new quality performance measures will be posted on the Secretary's website. The Secretary is required to post new quality performance measures for the Medicare program on their website. Payment rates under the program will not be lower than the RUG rates effective as of October 1, 2004, with adjustments made annually. The Secretary will develop methods to link payment rates to quality in consultation with the Institute of. The Secretary will develop and test methods to link payment rates under the Medicare program to quality indicators, with input from various stakeholders. This includes special payments for facilities that provide higher levels of direct care staffing. Testing will be done through pilot studies and demonstration projects. The Secretary will conduct a study on the adequacy of Medicaid financing for quality nursing facility care, including compliance with State and Federal laws. The Secretary will conduct a study on the financing of quality nursing facility care, including Medicaid adequacy, Medicare cross-subsidization, industry margins, trends impact, demographic changes, and options for payment and financing over the next five decades. Annual reports will be submitted to Congress until the final report is issued. The Secretary will submit annual reports to Congress on the amendments made to the Medicare payment system for extended care services in skilled nursing facilities. A final report, due within 5 years of the Act's enactment, will include study results, impact assessment, payment system recommendations, and analysis of alternative approaches to address identified issues.
